/COMMIT_MSG.message:
Depends-On: Ifa21fbcb41fcb77827997cce2d5e9266ba849b17
Story: #1755453
Task: 19319

I'm just imagining if I'm a user, and I'm in a directory with a bunch of templates. I upload them to a Swift container using the `orchestration template list files` command. After that I make some local modifications.

If I now do stack create without specifying a swift container, of course it uses my local, modified sources. But if I *do* specify a swift container... it still uses my local, modified sources. In fact there's no way to get it to use the sources from the swift container at all, unless I change directory. IMHO that violates the principle of least surprise.

In fact AFAICT it doesn't look like we have a mechanism to ever get the main (root) template from the swift container? AIUI heatclient always downloads the template and sends it inline, but what we actually need when it is a relative path and a swift container is specified is to send it as a relative URL so heat-engine can look in the swift container for it (did we implement that part on the engine side?).

>  In fact there's no way to get it to use the sources from the swift container at all

Yeah, user either syncs the local files with the container like TripleO every time or it will the use the ones in the container if the files are not available locally.

> In fact AFAICT it doesn't look like we have a mechanism to ever get the main (root) template from the swift container

AFAIK we send the root template body in API call and it's not in the files map, so the root template is always assumed to be picked from the local folder.

If we want to send the root template name only, it would possibly be API changes and IMO we should handle that later.

heatclient/common/template_utils.py.message:
That would be a question for Steve Baker. I think for some reason he wanted it to be unambiguous.

Changing it now would be dangerous for existing deployed stacks, because we know there are issues when updating stacks with new file names in some circumstances (as we discovered because of this feature and people doing updates from different paths).
I think I've addressed them in a proper way in the next patchset that would be backward compatible.

Probably I don't understand the whole gamut of issues here.

AIUI, we use the 'env_list_tracker' only for server side merging, to know the order of env files.

For patch update we already have an existing merged environment

For new env files they would be picked from the new path in the map[1].

[1] https://github.com/openstack/heat/blob/master/heat/common/environment_util.py#L165

I might have misunderstood the question.

files in the files dict have normalised (absolute) URLs, so I'd assume that's why we have to use them in the environment list for the server to merge.

This is going to mean that any local files available are going to override any files in the bucket. That seems unlikely to be what users are expecting - the default behaviour (looking locally) overriding the behaviour they've specifically requested (looking in a bucket).

It also means that we're not going to fail even in the case where we're clearly missing files - e.g. absolute URL (can't be a reference into the container) that doesn't exist.

Suggestion: maybe list the contents of the container at the beginning, and then for each file you encounter determine whether it is present in the URL or whether to go look for it locally. You could create a little class to cache the contents list.

> But it's really unfortunate because one of the goals of this feature is to allow us to eventually stop doing URL requests from the server at all

Not sure I get that, we can still stop all url requests from the server and suggest users to upload files to swift only.

> Maybe we should just ignore local files altogether when the user specifies a Swift container

That would have been easier to implement, but I feel that would more disruptive from the user point of view, unless they remember to upload all files to swift.

Though it would work for Tripleo as they upload everything.

> Not in the client, as the client does not know about what's in the file container.

It did know before though. If you had a URL like http://example.com/bogus then it would try to download it and fail. Now we've told it to also look in the Swift container it's claiming no knowledge, even though this file _cannot_ be in the Swift container (only relative paths should be in the Swift container).

> Are you suggesting to build a heatclient dependency with swiftclient? I thought we always wanted to avoid that.

I was, but you make a good point about dependencies.

> This is going to mean that any local files available are going to override any files in the bucket

yeah, that was my assumption from heatclient pov, unless user specifies that it's an object request like tripleoclient[1].

[1] https://github.com/openstack/python-tripleoclient/blob/master/tripleoclient/utils.py#L1138

> It also means that we're not going to fail even in the case where we're clearly missing files.

Not in the client, as the client does not know about what's in the file container.

> maybe list the contents of the container at the beginning

Are you suggesting to build a heatclient dependency with swiftclient? I thought we always wanted to avoid that.

> It also means that we're not going to fail even in the case where we're clearly missing files.

That's also one of the reason why I had the files_list in the earlier API, so that we know what all files we can assume to be in swift.

> even though this file _cannot_ be in the Swift container (only relative paths should be in the Swift container).

With the current API, do you have any better solution? It would fail but fail in the server.

> With the current API, do you have any better solution? It would fail but fail in the server.

It's hard to think of a better solution without adding the swiftclient dependency. But it's really unfortunate because one of the goals of this feature is to allow us to eventually stop doing URL requests from the server at all, but this change means we'll end up doing more of them.

Maybe we should just ignore local files altogether when the user specifies a Swift container, and assume that everything is a relative path inside the container (including the template URL if it is a relative path). That doesn't prevent Heat from trying to load any absolute URLs it finds in templates from the container though.

doc/source/developer/specs/circular-depe.message: Zuul could automatically push a revert which would be a regular push, not a force-push.  I do agree that force-pushes are problematic and we should avoid them.
I think even pushing a revert might make the situation worse than just properly reporting what succeeded and what failed and fall back to human intervention for resolving the inconsistent state.

In our previous discussions on the topic, we generally considered "Zuul push", ie, having Zuul push the merge rather than asking Gerrit or GitHub to do it, to be a pre-requisite for this, because we thought that errors (for example, due to merge or permissions discrepancies between Zuul and the code review system) were likely and error recovery (by reverting previously merged patches) was important.  I still think that's the best way to handle it, so I think we should look into that.

In both Gerrit and GitHub's case, if Zuul pushes a commit for a change/PR, the change/PR will be closed.  And it should be a simple matter to add a "push" command to the merger.
Agree, that this could be added. However, IIRC with Github Apps it is not possible to allow pushes to a protected branch. So this would be mainly useful for Gerrit.

Yeah - which is super sad making.

Perhaps when we look at "Zuul push" we could consider allowing a "push" account to be configured in the github driver that would be a regular account for Zuul to use to push things, separate from the App. (it's an ugly workaround, but such is life)

Using a push account is not really feasible from my role as an operator of a large scale multi tenant setup.

However where we support it (probably all but Github) we should be able to use it in order to at least rule out algorithmic differences between different git versions/implementations.

But I'm not sure if we can just default to push in Gerrit or make that configurable separately per project (I guess in Gerrit we might need different permissions for push than submit).

That said I think we should make this as best effort as possible but don't try to 'repair' things if they still go wrong. And we should make this very clean in the docs that this is a tradeof that has to be made when allowing circular dependencies.

@Monty: Configuration of this feature is mentioned here (together with the note that it's off by default)

@Simon: We should also add a config option to completely disallow this in the whole tenant. Or we allow them in the tenant and enable per repo.
Ok, will add that this must be enabled explicitly in the tenant config.

Maybe it makes sense to elaborate a little bit more about that. Reading further down it becomes clear that the intention is to enqueue one queue item for each change in the cycle and hold back reporting until the whole cycle is finished. This is the essential part that makes it possible to enqueue such a cycle over multiple change queues.
Will do.
If we hold back the reporting until the whole bundle is finished we actually have all the needed information already. So in fact we could report each item in one go with the bundle result.

The reason for holding back the bundle reporting is that we don't know at this point if all items could be merged. We could of course assume (the very likely) happy path and report the whole bundle. Then we only have to come back and report again in the error case.
We should add the standard header from the other specs about how this is not authoritative documentation.
Done

Why should it be configured per-project?  Per-tenant seems enough to me.  Is there a use-case for multiple projects within a tenant having differing values for this?  I think that would make it confusing for users?  Though I guess you don't have to use that feature, and if you don't the tenant default would control?
nit: trailing whitespace

Apparently I guessed wrongly above.  Users probably will too.  Oh, and this is still in the tenant config, this isn't a project-level config.  In that case, why would you even have a tenant-level setting?

Ok the "need to be enabled" reads to me like: in order to enable it, you must explicitly set both the tenant and project settings to true.  I'd suggest saying something like "In addition, the tenant default may be overridden on a per-project basis".  I agree that the exclude-unprotected-branches pattern makes sense here.
The intention was setting the default on tenant level and allowing to override this on a per project level similar to exclude-unprotected branches. I guess that needs a little bit more words.

IIRC the initial idea was, that you have to explicitly allow circular dependencies on the tenant AND project level. However, I think the current implementation that is similar to exclude-unprotected-branches makes more sense. Will fix.

/COMMIT_MSG.message: What is the scope of the changes that could happen at runtime? Could we be creating a situation where a runtime config change could result in the clock on a host being jumped by hours or days (either forward or backward)? We don't allow ntp config changes at runtime for exactly that reason - software breaks when the clock changes by large intervals.
The puppet change will now ensure runtime ptp manifest is applied with -F 0. This ensures the clock will not be stepped at runtime, only at startup.
How will the user know that the updated ptp config hasn't been applied and this extra step is required?
Hosts still go config out of date as before. Changing the host clock sync type still requires a reboot. If the puppet apply fails the host will stay config out of date.

sysinv/sysinv/sysinv/sysinv/conductor/ma.message: How would it be OK for a non uuid to be passed into this function? Shouldn't this raise an exception since it is a coding error?

I believe there are cases where the config is 'install'
If that's no longer the case I can revert this change.
Maybe John would know. Are you saying you made this change before you saw any issues?
To avoid hitting cases with a non-uuid config target I've added a check to ensure the host is unlocked. With that I've reverted this change as its no longer needed.
config changes will not be setting 'install' as the uuid; it is only reported on initial install when there are no config changes noted.
How do we handle the case where we are disabling PTP for a host?

Switching the clock sync is handled by the host api and is a reboot required change. We won't run the ptp runtime manifest if the config target is reboot required. So this will only be used to apply ptp changes, not go between ptp/ntp.
for the hosts in ptp_hosts which are not config_apply_runtime_manifest() do we still need to ensure reboot_required is set via _config_update_hosts(..., reboot_required=True) ?
No. Either they'll pickup the change during the next unlock or they will be able to apply the manifest at a later time.

puppet-manifests/src/modules/platform/ma.message: Why did you take these out? Don can confirm, but I thought we disabled the "enable" functionality in the service resource, which meant that the separate enable (and stop) step was always required.

If you do a grep on "systemctl enable" in this repo you will see that we do the separate enable for pretty much everywhere we declare a controller service. From what Don says it seems like this is necessary to support DORs. I'm not comfortable changing this here.
I did it to simplify my changes. I didn't see any issues during my testing. Going from NTP->PTP->NTP enabled/disabled started/stopped services as expected.

https://opendev.org/starlingx/integ/src/branch/master/config/puppet-4.8.2/centos/patches/1004-Block-enabling-of-services.patch

There was an issue with chkconfig where it would automatically enable services based on chkconfig flags in init scripts
spelling
why is it necessary to query the status here?
Correct, the service failed to start and the service resource didn't catch the failure.
Service "ensure => running" should fail if the service is not running. It runs "systemctl is-active <service>", I believe, and would fail otherwise. The "enable=>true" would be a no-op.

Service enable => running doesn't actually ensure the process is running. It will attempt to start the service, but if that fails (eg if the config is invalid) it will continue. This ensures the service is running, and will fail the manifest otherwise.

I'm not sure what you're saying here. You simulated a failure to launch and the "service" resource didn't notice the failure? That seems like an issue. Or is it launching and failing and needs retries?

This is a problem. The /usr/lib/systemd/system/phc2sys.service file is an installed file, owned by linuxptp, and is not packaged as a config file. It should not be modified. Generated service files like this should be written to /etc/systemd/system/
I don't know why this was configured like this. We don't have any parameters in the template, so it's not really doing anything.

These seem to add no value, unless you're suggesting there's a problem with the "service" resource and that it fails to detect a failure to launch a service - which seems odd, given that we often see failures due to exactly this.

Maybe it's a timing issue or something odd about the ptp4l process. If I run systemctl is-active ptp4l manually it returns an error so I don't know why puppet doesn't pick it up. As is the status command is necessary to detect failures.

The .service files being generated from templates have a - in the ExecStart, which tells systemd to ignore the return status of the command. So systemd thinks the start request was successful, when it really wasn't.

https://opendev.org/starlingx/stx-puppet/src/branch/master/puppet-manifests/src/modules/platform/templates/phc2sys.service.erb#L8
https://opendev.org/starlingx/stx-puppet/src/branch/master/puppet-manifests/src/modules/platform/templates/ptp4l.service.erb#L9

Remove the hyphen, and you shouldn't need these status commands.

And as noted above, these should be written to /etc/systemd/system so they're not replacing the installed files. systemd will look there first.

pkg/k8sdeps/interfaces.go.message: I don't think these are necessary - if you need a "temporary" filesystem, you should use fs.MakeFakeFS

As i explained in the a comment to the commit, currently kubectl apply modules support working with file system or stdin only(not any reader, stdin of the process, this is coded into kubectl apply behavior). Process can not write to its own stdin without ugly hacks. So the only way for us to use kubectl apply is to use real files on filesystem (temporary in our case, the /tmp one, these are actual files that are written on the disk), Kubectl builder will then read from the actual file system, not reader interface. it will take the path to file(s) string, and use it to read from filesystem using. FakeFS from kustomize module does not provide ability to create actual files on file system, it stores them as structs, so when kubectl apply will not be able to see them, as it uses os.Open(path). That is why i have extended filesystem with ability to create temporary files, and not in memory mocking object.

do we have to make sure physical_network == physnet for the opflex case then?

In this case we don't - there isn't really a meaning for physical_network in networks with opflex type static segments. One purpose of physical_networks in OpenStack is to define a domain of segmentation IDs per segment type (e.g. vlan type networks have a set of IDs to allocate per physnet, as specified in this configuration variable for neutron-server: https://opendev.org/openstack/neutron/src/branch/master/neutron/conf/plugins/ml2/drivers/driver_type.py#L68-L76). With opflex type networks, OpenStack doesn't allocate the IDs, because ACI handles this, so this isn't necessary. Therefore we don't make a check for physical_networks.

Would it make sense to move this non-opflex segment case before the opflex segment case? Even if its not tested or supported yet (I'm not sure), we probably want to bind immediately to VLAN segments, whether they are static or dynamic, if they have the proper physnet. Then, if we can't bind directly to any of the existing segments, we'll try creating a dynamic segment (on the proper physnet). 

In fact, we probably want to iterate separately over segments_to_bind for each section, so we first bind directly if any supported non-opflex segment is on the proper physnet, then, only if that's not possible, create a dynamic segment. 

The reason I think the order matters is that we could need to create a dynamic segment in the case where we only have a (static) VLAN segment, but that segment is considered equivalent to an opflex segment.  We don't seem to support that yet, but when we do, we'll want to make sure to bind any existing segment if possible before creating a dynamic segment.
Okay - after discussing this, I think I can see your point. Will change.

My thinking was that static opflex segments would be at the top-level of the hierarchy, if they were present at all, and lower levels wouldn't have opflex segments (our MD currently only allocates VLAN dynamic segments). It's not clear to me what use cases there were beyond the current binding behavior, so my goal was to just address the port-binding behavior needed for existing workflows. I'm open to changing this, but I'd like to understand the possible use cases before incorporating those changes in this patch.

We can ignore possible future use cases, such as a static VLAN segment with a different physnet than is needed. Even then, I think it is clearer and safer to complete a binding to an existing segment if possible before bothering to create a dynamic segment. 

Therefore, even just for the opflex+HBP use case, I still feel this method should first iterate over segments_to_bind looking for a VLAN segment for which it can complete the binding. Only if none is found should it proceed to iterate over the segments_to_bind again, looking for an opflex segment and creating a dynamic VLAN segment.

As an example, with the current patch, if someone happened to use the multiprovidernet extension to create a network with both an opflex static segment and a bindable VLAN static segment, I think we'd end up creating an unneeded dynamic segment. I think completing a binding if possible always makes sense before trying to create a dynamic segment, and maybe never actually binding to either the static or dynamic VLAN segment.

heatclient/osc/v1/template.py.message:
What does the output of this look like?

I know osc is very big on drawing ascii-art boxes around things for some mysterious reason, but in this case you'll want to just get some plain text that you can pipe to another command approximately 100% of the time.

I know it wouldn't be consistent with the rest of the CLI interface, but I'd personally prefer it just did that rather than requiring you to pass like 15 obscure command line flags to get it to do the sane thing.

osc supports all kinds of formats

[-f {json,shell,table,value,yaml}]

Default is yaml, that would look something like 

template: file:///home/stack/templates/rsg_test.yaml
files:
- file:///home/stack/templates/server.yaml
- file:///home/stack/templates/env.yaml

So here's my concern: as a user what I want this command to do for me is allow me to write:

  openstack object create my-container $(openstack orchestration template list files my-template.yaml)

and having structured data here doesn't allow that by default - in fact I suspect it doesn't even allow that if you explicitly pass "-f shell".

I think my ideal would be that by default it just returns a flat list of files in a format suitable for running the above command (so I guess -f shell, because it will need shell escaping?), but maybe if you specify a format like "-f yaml" then it could provide it in a structured way like this.

Yeah a decorator would have been a little cleaner, but I am fine with the current state, as it is readable as well, and limited to this very simple case...

What do you think about to do a sleep few seconds before retrying?

Tenacity usage is not allowed but we could easily simulate some parts here, we could only retry once but with a tiny delay to increase the likeliwood to see loading become successful.

I don't know why gerrit fail to respond here, but I suppose system load could explain why, so by pausing execution few seconds we could let gerrit freeing resources and so avoid failing, without longer Zuul blocking, and we could increase our likelywood to success, I think it's better than  wast resources by asking for recheck if loading fail one more time.

It could be a good compromise between resources usages and probabilities to success.

Thoughts?

tripleo_ansible/roles/tripleo_bootstrap/.message: shouldn't we recreate it from scratch instead?

We get into this situation when using upload-puppet-modules to patch puppet on overcloud nodes. It overwrites the symlinks in /etc/puppet/modules with a full copy of the (patched) puppet code. This all works fine the first time, but subsequent stack updates fail when this task wants to generate a fresh set of symlinks.

I'm sure we could add tasks to properly handle directories, but bear in mind the whole purpose of this task doing a global symlink is to improve performance (see [1]). Adding tasks to accommodate side effects of using upload-puppet-modules (mainly a dev tool) would be counterproductive.

[1] https://review.opendev.org/683277

rabbitmq/values.yaml.message: This setting triggers probe before the current one times out. We'll have probes running in parallel, which caused a few  problems. Can you set the timeoutSeconds less than periodSeconds?
Agreed. I've increased the period a little bit in order to lower the timeout to a value smaller than the period.
If the probe template is same for both liveness and readiness probes, why the periodSeconds and timeoutSeconds differ?

Liveness probes are almost always set to have longer initial delays, periods of execution, and occasionally timeouts. The reason being a liveness probe will forcefully kill the process if the probe fails as it's assumed the process is truly borked and has been unready/unresponsive for some period of time, whereas the readiness probe just indicates the process is unready but has the potential to recover. It does not make sense to have these two probes that serve two very different purposes have the same execution periods and timeouts.

I think the *cache* proposed in this spec are shared across the entire host. Even so, maybe there is a maximum number for VMs to share the cache to ensure a fair performance improvement. Too many VMs competing the share cache may make it worse then even with out the cache.

Typically (in our customer's environment) one fast NVME SSD for one node. This SSD would act as a shared cache pool for all the VMs in the compute node. So every instance just share this SSD. Will not give a cache device to a specific instance.

The cache mechanism is:
e.g.
cache device mount point is: /dev/nvme1n1
remote slow volume mount points are: /dev/sdc, /dev/sdd.
Then /dev/nvme1n1 can cache for /dev/sdc, /dev/sdd. Emulated volume for /dev/sdc would be something like /dev/cas-1, /dev/sdd would be /dev/cas-2 for example. Then /dev/cas-1 be assigned to VM1, /dev/cas-2 be assigned to VM2. There can be lots of /dev/cas-xxx, and they share the same cache pool(the fast SSD).

There will not be the case that there's no sufficient space on the cache device, because no fixed size of cache allocated to a volume. If the io of a volume is busy, then the blocks will be cached; if the cached blocks has not been touched for a long time, then it will be wiped. Cache software will cache the blocks as much as possible, but if cache is full, it will wipe old data.

So my understanding of the use case:

* Cinder can state if a volume is local cacheable or not.
* Deployer can configure local cache on compute and configure nova-compute to use that local cache
* Deployer can create (a premium) flavor that requests volume local caching
* User can decide that she is willing to pay some extra for a faster volume so selects the above premium flavor for her server

Now:
* Nova has to place the server to a compute which supports caching.
* The libvirt driver needs to set up the volume to be cached via os-brick.

So, if there is no way to cache the volume then such request needs to be re-scheduled or rejected.

Also if the volume is not cacheable then requesting to caches it is a contradiction. I can imagine that the end user would be pretty sad that she paid for the premium flavor with volume local cache but got no locally cached volume as cinder marked the volumes as non cacheable. 

Also an interesting question what should happen if an server create request includes two volumes and a flavor with local cached required. But one of the volumes are marked non cacheable by cinder while the other is marked cacheable by cinder
and the flavor requested such caching

* Add COMPUTE_SUPPORT_VOLUME_CACHE trait to os-traits

* add a new compute capability that maps to this trait

* enable this capability in the libvirt driver if a caches is configured

This is a long sentence! Might help reordering. "The VMT will not track or issue advisories for external software components. Only source code provided by official OpenStack project teams is eligible for support from VMT."

It's not intended to be a change in policy. When the VMT was first formed, OpenStack did not distribute binary artifacts at all, and the deliverables which are presently overseen are implemented in pure Python so are effectively only releasing source code. As of https://governance.openstack.org/tc/resolutions/20170530-binary-artifacts.html the TC allows official teams to release some binary artifacts under specific conditions, and so projects which engage in that kind of activity may seek out VMT coordination for vulnerabilities in their deliverables. Entry #7 here is less of a requirement, and more of a safeguard to set expectations for those projects that the VMT won't be issuing advisories for, say, a vulnerable version of glibc in one of their published container images.

Sorry I am new to this topic, and I am not really sure if this is a change of policy or not.

In other words, I understand why we would limit in scope of only the software code we produce, but does it make sense to be able to assert the tag that we "manage" vulns if we don't fully do it? (I am concerned about sending a wrong message).
Done.

/COMMIT_MSG.message:
Cinderclient is not the boss of us.  Looking at cinderclient is how you discovered the bug, but it's a cinder bug, not a cinderclient bug.  The v3 API has a resource_filters API that's supposed to list the available filters for various resources, introduced in Pike as part of the generalized-filtering-for-cinder-list-resource blueprint.  So the problem is that "display_name" is nowhere mentioned in that response, thus, cinderclient is doing the correct thing and the REST API is not.
A further problem is that the default resource_filters file appears to be out of date (volume_transfers isn't listed as a filterable resource).  An even further problem is that I think  the resources listed in that file are incorrect (they're all singular (e.g., "volume") whereas the actual resource name occuring in the URL for these list-whatever responses are plural.

I think the workaround you have coded, that is, to accept both 'name' and 'display_name' is OK -- as you pointed out, there's precedent in the list-snapshots code, and also, it will be nice not to break those users who have figured out that they have to use 'display_name' to get the volume-transfers-list response filtered by name.

So to get back to this commit message, what you should say is that you are fixing a bug where the "name" filter is not being recognized by the API, and you can mention that we'll silently continue to recognize "display_name" as an alias for this filter so as not to break current users who have figured out the workaround.
Done
I suggest adding "Instead, it allowed filtering on 'display_name', which is not the actual name of any attribute of the resource."
Done
I suggest adding "so as not to break people who have figured out the workaround".
Done

``GET /v3/{project_id}/volume-transfers/detail``) were not recognizing ``name``
as a filterable attribute.  That has been fixed in the current release.

(I don't know that we want to mention display_name if we're being silent about it!)

Done

1) we are allowing support for 'name' filtering

src/metadata.yaml.message: Dunno but this feels the wrong way around - neutron-openvswitch is in requires, nor provides?

I did take a dive into the juju docs about it, and they appear to assert that a subordinate should have one requires relation with scope container [0][1], the implicit juju-info relation is also defined like that. This subsequently makes the principal the provides side of the relation.

I know we have done it the opposite way for some of our existing subordinate relations, and I agree that the wording feels backward, i.e in effect the subordinate is the one providing something to the principal. But I could not unsee the documentation, so I adhered to it :)

0: https://jaas.ai/docs/charm-writing/relations
1: https://discourse.jujucharms.com/t/subordinate-applications/1053
Having said that, we do it this way across all our charms, so I'll change these so we're at least consistent.

manifests/wsgi/apache.pp.message:
What we really want here is 1 WSGI process per CPU, with a min cap of 2 and max cap of 12 to prevent problems on systems with large numbers of CPUs.  We used "os_workers" to satisfy this before, which is defined as:

    [ [ (processors.to_i / 2), 2 ].max, 12 ].min

This worked since we had both "keystone_main" and "keystone_admin", which both configure their own WSGI processes.

Unfortunately, there is not an equivalent of what we want in openstacklib as seen in https://github.com/openstack/puppet-openstacklib/blob/master/lib/facter/os_workers.rb

The proposal of using multiplication in this patch has the potential of resulting in 24 keystone processes on systems with 24 or more CPUs.  This exceeds our desired max cap, though the previous split of "keystone_main" and "keystone_admin" had the same issue from what I can see.

I think what we really want is this:

    [ [ processors.to_i, 2 ].max, 12 ].min

We have to keep in mind that, before, we had 2 wsgi processes with, each, 2 workers. Meaning 4 workers, taking keystone workload.
Now, with your proposal, we'd have to manage the same workload with only 2 workers - this isn't good, and this led to the current patch.

Taking your formula, we can set "min" to 4 instead of 2, and max to 24 in order to keep the same capability as before (2 processes, 12 workers each, and so on).

Maybe we should, instead of putting "$::os_workers*2", be more explicit and define there the intended value. Not really sure what's the best.

In any cases, we can't expect to keep the same workload and reduce the workers :).

You are correct about the previous behavior, though I recall that the intent when changes were made in this area was to use a max cap of 8 for keystone (which was later increased to 12 I believe).  We wanted to avoid too many workers, as it could result in issues such as overwhelming connections to a database when it is shared by other services.

The safe approach right now would be to mimic the previous behavior.  I do think being more explicit here (and adding a comment) would be better than just using "$::os_workers * 2", as it will make our intent clear.
You're missing a ',' here, which is breaking the CI job.
this value is not correct puppet dsl. This is the code if it was in ruby (like in the fact code) but is not correct for .pp files.  min($::os_workers, 4) is likely what you'd want.
Thanks for the tip, Alex. New patch set on the way.
Disregard, I noticed you uploaded on already. Thanks!

I'm afraid that I'm too late to raise this, but I'd prefer to see this implementation in openstacklib instead of puppet-keystone.

We already have the one for heat engine[1], so it makes more sense to me to have all worker calculators in one place.

[1] https://github.com/openstack/puppet-openstacklib/blob/master/lib/facter/os_workers.rb#L52-L63

Yes, I believe you are correct.  This shouldn't be changed.
